properties.title: /// Photogrammetric Fab Scanner ///
properties.scope: What I feel may be useful in the Photogrammetric Fab Scanner, is to use only one camera; combined with the rotation of the object to be scanned, it allows the realization of a series of aligned photos. This automated process drastically reduces the costs of the photogrammetric scan
properties.description:
The Photogrammetric Fab Scanner is a cylindrical closed box of diameter 50 cm.


The process that I was aiming to automize inside this box was a realization of a photographic session using the photogrammetric technique. This would produce the images necessary for the creation of a 3D model complete with texture.

The original idea was to rotate the article to be scanned on itself, rather than rotate the photographic camera around the article and produce the necessary photographs in definite and difference functional positions for the development of the model.

The photographs will then be united using a specific photogrammetric software program.

///

The Photogrammetric Fab Scanner consists of 3 different parts that work in a direct relationship :

- A - The Light Box
- B - The Motorized Stepper Dish
- C - The Motorized Camera Curved Rail

The object to scan will be positioned on the Motorized Stepper Dish.

When the back doors of the scanner are locked down, the process commences:


--> The LED lights are on, the photographic camera will take a picture at every 15° angle of the rotation support (24 photos).


--> Once the 360° rotation has been completed, the camera moves in the new position, and the "rotation / shooting" process starts again.


--> The radial movement increases after each 45°.


--> The complete process consists of 4 different positions along the camera rail from the top part to the low part : +90° (just 1 photo is required) / +45°/ 0°/ -45°


--> Each one corresponds to a 360° rotation dish and a set of 24 photos.

///

At the end of the process, we will have an appropriate number of aligned pictures to allow us to create a 3D Photogrammetric Mesh
properties.faq:
--> Is the Photogrammetric Fab Scanner already working? 

After they were produced, some elements have proved to be weak or not sufficiently precise, in relation to the technical demands of the project. 

This means that the project necessitates a new stage of development. 
And this is the reason why I have not uploaded a video of the working project. 

I will upload it later when the V1 of the Photogrammetric Fab Scan is ready

MORE--> http://fabacademy.org/archives/2015/eu/students/de_palo.pierluigi/exercise18.html


--> Is it still under development? 

Off course!! i need your help Word to finalize and upgrade the  Photogrammetric Fab Scanner until the V1 version

Please contact me : -->  http://fabacademy.org/archives/2015/eu/students/de_palo.pierluigi/about.html


--> Which camera is it used?

Is the HackHD camera

The innovation, in our opinion, it's not just go in depth on the same solution, but also rise your head and look forward, look for something new.

properties.title: X-Culpt CNC
properties.scope:
Our objective was to be able to find most of the materials easily at a local hardware store, also be able to reproduce the 40% of the pieces with the same machine.

Also the ide is to create an open source digital fabrication tool, for small fab labs or fablabs with less resources.
properties.description:
Its a  fabable low_cost MDF CNC machine. Our objective was to be able to find most of the materials easily at a local hardware store. all the parts were milled form one and a half 18mm MDF sheets on a shopbot, the milling took about 7 hours. the linear rails are made from  1 inch 90° aluminum extrusions as a track for regular skate bearings, the motion system are made with standar UNC threads of 5/16 inch and braze nuts pulled by NEMA 23 steper motors.
The electronic sistem is controlled by an Arduino UNO with TB 6600 drivers and works with an ATX hacked power supply and the controller software is GBRL latest version and universal G-code sender 1.8.
properties.faq:
What will it do?
Cut 2D and 3D parts

How much it will cost?
About 350 USD

Who’s done what beforehand?
A lot of companies make cnc routers but the costs are high and for the most of the cheaper ones you have to pay for the building plans.

What processes will be used?
Cnc milling, drilling, pcb routing and some manual assembling

Can all be made on a fab lab?
Yes

lab.blurb: Como primer laboratorio de Sudamérica en crearse y al ubicarse dentro de una universidad nacional su misión es potenciar la investigación y educación por medio de la fabricación digital.
lab.description:
El Fab Lab UNI es la iniciativa más importante en Perú por llevar lo último del arte, la fabricación digital, las herramientas de diseño y del conocimiento relacionado con la invención, la innovación y la educación técnica superior al Perú y a Sudamérica, para todos los segmentos de la sociedad.

Nace el año 2010 por iniciativa del Instituto de Arquitectura Avanzada de Cataluña (iaac.net) y la Agencia Española de Cooperación Internacional para el Desarrollo (aecid.es) quien financia la capacitación técnica e instalación del primer Fab Lab de sudamérica en la Facultad de Arquitectura de la Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería (uni.edu.pe).
lab.name: Fab Lab UNI
lab.address_notes: Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería, Facultad de Arquitectura, Urbanismo y Artes.

properties.title: TalkingBits
properties.scope: The scope of the project is the fabrication and development of an Open Source and Ultra low cost integrated solution to measure, control and monitor energy consumption of devices.
properties.description:
# Description
TalkingBits is an Ultra Low Cost and Open Source full integrated solution for IoT based on **NodeMCU** as hardware and **freeboard.io** and **dweet.io** as open source platforms visualizing and storage of all kind of data. It has been developed for the SmartEMMA contest sponsored by AXPO. The final goal is find a cheap and fabbable version of a connected energy meter with data easy to understand.
# Components
### 1. The Hardware (working prototype)
The basic element of hardware is the Smart plug . An open source small plug that you put between the wall socket and the appliance and it is supercharged with the following features:
* Lasercut acrilic frame by layers 
* Energy meter to monitor power consumption up to 20 Amps
* Solid state relay to be able to switch ON and OFF the device remotely
* Wireless WIFI connection provided by NodeMCU
* LDR light sensor to automate ON/OFF cycles
* Temperature sensor to automate ON/OFF cycles in temperature dependant devices.
That allows every Smart Plug to be independently monitored and controlled via Web or Mobile App.
### 2. Android App (under development)
IoT Android App is an Open source Android app developed using App Inventor that allows you to control and monitor Smart Plugs. Even kids can learn how to expand and grow this open source app to suit their needs and visual appearance.
### 3. Modular IoT control panel (working prototype)
Web IoT Control Panel is a combination of JS applets, HTML templates and database that allows a user to store data sent from the sensors and to analyze and display them in a neat, simple and understandable way like a control panel. This can be embedded in existing web pages and can be used for Smart Plugs and any other kind of sensor like water meters, gas meters, weather stations, etc. It is based in the open source **freeboard.io** and **dweet.io** as open source platforms for visualizing and store of all kind of data. Freeboard allows to integrate also other kinds of data like weather stations and JSON streams.
properties.faq:
# What is the cost and license of the hardware?
All the hardware is Open Source under MIT license. The cost of the hardware is less than 10 EUR per smartplug considering prototype quantities locally made in a fab lab. Industrial reproduction of the device could be achieved for a fraction of the cost.
# What is the cost of the software?
All the software, including microcontroller program, web and Android app are Open Source licensed under MIT license and free of charge.
# Do you have a working prototype?
A working prototype of a Smart Plug connected to a 3D printer located in The Beach Lab Sitges can be seen [here](https://freeboard.io/board/20A3T1)

lab.blurb: The Beach Lab is digital fabrication organization based in the coast of Sitges, a town 25 miles south of Barcelona. Member of the Fab Lab network since January 2014.
lab.description:
The Beach Lab started originally as a fixed-only installation based in Sitges and during 2016 has developed a research mobile lab project called The Tesseract. 

Unlike traditional mobile labs, where tools are carried, but can only be used when the vehicle is static, structural engineering and seismic design techniques used for tall buildings -like tension cables and damping- have been applied to design a lightweight cubic structure (The Tesseract) that allows The Beach Lab to use digital fabrication tools on the go, by road, sea and air.

The foldable and developable nature of The Tesseract allows the Beach Lab to seamlessly switch from mobile to fixed installation. This gives the flexibility to to develop educational programs and workshops when required, optimizing the resources when they are not needed. Incidentally it created an interesting concept of unallocated lab, not necessarily tied to a particular city.

The current iteration of The Tesseract incorporates Fab Lab 1.0 machines
lab.name: The Beach Lab
lab.address_notes: Live location of mobile labs to be implemented

properties.title: Autonomous
properties.scope:
The scope of Autonomous is covering the energy topic of the subject of sustainable development. The project was iniciated  because I wanted to gain hands-on experience with solar and wind power harvesting, battery charging and electric vehicles.
Therefore, the easyest way to start was to use laptop batteries to drive an electric bike and to learn how these Li-ion batteries can be charged by solar cells. It was clear to me that if I accomplish this task, I will gain enough experience in order to build power supply that can satisfy most of mine personal electric needs without useing the public grid. These are computing, cooling, lightening, audio and transportation. The only exceptions seems to be the heating and cooking where thousands of watts are needed if conventional devices are used. Overall, this project is a fun way of getting into the personal power supply field and this is one of the main reasons to be called Autonomous.
properties.description:
The purpose of the project of Autonomous is to develop a trailer that can be attached to any e-bike, pedelecs (from pedalled electric cycle), and EPAC (electric power-assisted cycles) which refer to bicycles that have an electric motor and rechargeable batteries to assist the power provided by the rider [1]. This trailer has to be equipped with solar cells and a portable wind turbine so it must work as an autonomous charging station. Thus, the rider of the bike will be able to have an average of 60km mileage per
day with just a light assistance. Also there will be enough space for the camping equipment needed for a long distance travelling.

Why Autonomous? 
     The Autonomous project aims to develop an alternative way for medium and long distance transportation. The targeted customers are the pedalecs users who would like to upgrade their equipment for national and international travels. Moreover, Autonomous provides an alternative way for energizing the battery of the pedalecs which reduces the cost for transportation and gives the freedom of recharging the e-bike at any place.

How is this good?
     On a global scale there is a large amount of pedalecs on the road and currently unfolding European e-bike market [1]. Thus, there is a possibility in front of Autonomous to change the way of how the batteries of these e-bikes are charged. More precisely, the ability of Autonomous to recharge every e-bike battery from the solar power is in-line with the global movement for cleaner future with much less carbon emissions and as less fossil fuel as possible. In this direction, Autonomous reduce the fossil fuel usage by charging e-bikes ’out-off the grid’. This reduces the demand for electricity from the grid which is mostly made out of coal [2] and this way reduces CO2 emissions because the process of producing electricity from coal is the greatest greenhouse emitter worldwide. By using Autonomous, every e-biker will be able to charge his bike without worrying about the power supply and this way it is proved that a long distance travels are achievable without an extreme efforts. A proof of this are Tour de Mongolia, Suntrip (from Italy, Milano to Kazakhstan, Astana) and the France-Japan expedition of Florian Bailly. All of the participants of these trips, that are thousands of kilometres long, have used solar trailers to recharge their electric bikes. In a long term, Autonomous will teach its users about the possibilities for solar powered travelling. As scientists expect much more effective PV to come [3] the knowledge of electric vehicles coupled with solar installations is something that has to be promoted to the society for the everybody’s benefit of cleaner planet Earth.

What is the innovation and the future work?
     The concept of solar trailer for pedalecs is relatively new but it is already proven at a couple of long distance travels and competitions. For the purpose, a DIY Li-ion battery pack with the very efficient 18650 cells was assembled out of six-cell laptop batteries. The transformation of the laptop batteries was made in an original way by using minimal additional soldering. However, the Li-ion batteries are very delicate when it comes to recharging. Hence, the main problem was to overcome the difficulty of charging Li-ion cells from solar panels in a safe way. This was nicely done by using conventional Li-ion charger with DC input. Thus, after the battery was built and charging was conducted, everything else was just assembling the bits of the e-bike kit, the trailer and the wiring. Now, one can follow the step-by-step DIY instruction below and create his own electric bike with Li-ion battery pack that is capable to be recharged from different energy sources.
     The future plan for Autonomous includes a portable wind turbine, a rare concept proposed once by Paul Smith in his trailer Navitas. However, Navitas seems not to be brought to the production thus, if Autonomous complete this task it will be the only wind harvesting trailer on the market. Moreover, in the future, when the current prototype passes some tests, a specially shaped fractal solar panels [4] will be applied, so the solar power could be harvested in a much more efficient way.

Acknowledgement
      Autonomous started in FabLab BCN under the Erasmus for Young Entreprenuers program thanks to the Bulgarian Charities Aid Foundation and Fundació Catalana per a la Recerca i la Innovació.

References
[1] “The Global E-bike Market”, INSG Insight-No. 23, September 2014.
[2] “Sources of Greenhouse Gas Emissions”
http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/ghgemissions/sources.html
[3] “Solar cell efficiency”
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/PVeff%28rev150806%29.jpg/1024px-PVeff%28rev150806%29.jpg
[4] “Solar Energy Generation in Three Dimensions”
http://arxiv.org/pdf/1112.3266v2.pdf
